title: 112_hr6527
content: The Act may be cited as the "Women Veterans and Other Health Care Improvements Act of 2012" and includes a table of contents. The "Women Veterans and Other Health Care Improvements Act of 2012" includes provisions for reproduction and infertility research, fertility counseling and treatment for veterans, care delivery for spouses and surrogates of veterans, improvement of women veterans call center, counseling pilot programs for women veterans, and assistance for child care for certain veterans. The "Women Veterans and Other Health Care Improvements Act of 2012" includes provisions for facilitating reproduction and infertility research to meet the long-term reproductive health care needs of veterans with genitourinary disabilities or conditions incurred in line of duty. The Secretary of Defense and the Director of the National Institutes of Health will collaborate on research to improve veterans' ability to reproduce, particularly those with spinal cord injuries affecting reproduction. The Secretary will also disseminate research information for the benefit of Veterans Health activities. The Women Veterans and Other Health Care Improvements Act of 2012 includes provisions for disseminating research information for the benefit of Veterans Health activities. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 73. The Act mandates the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to report on reproduction and infertility research activities. Fertility counseling and treatment are now recognized as medical services for veterans. Reproductive treatment and care delivery are extended to spouses and surrogates of veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to provide fertility counseling and treatment, including assisted reproductive technology, to spouses or surrogates of severely wounded veterans with infertility conditions incurred in the line of duty. Coordination of care is also available for other spouses and surrogates seeking fertility services. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may coordinate fertility counseling and treatment for spouses or surrogates seeking fertility services. A new section is added to the table of sections in chapter 17 of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will enhance the women veterans call center to assist with accessing healthcare and benefits. Regulations will be prescribed to provide reproductive treatment for spouses and surrogates of veterans. SEC. 6 of the Caregivers and Veterans Omnibus Health Services Act of 2010 is amended to increase the number of locations for counseling in retreat settings for women veterans from three to 14 and extend the duration from two years to four years. SEC. 7 establishes pilot programs to provide assistance for child care for certain veterans. (a) Modification of Duration of Pilot Program on Assistance for Child Care for Certain Veterans Receiving Health Care. The duration of the child care center established as part of the pilot program may operate until two years after the establishment of the pilot program in the third Veterans Integrated Service Network. (b) Requirement for Pilot Program on Assistance for Child Care for Certain Veterans Receiving Readjustment Counseling and Related Mental Health Services. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to carry out a pilot program to assess the feasibility and advisability of providing assistance for child care for certain veterans. The pilot program assesses the feasibility of providing assistance to qualified veterans who are primary caretakers of children to obtain child care while receiving readjustment counseling and related mental health services at a Vet Center. Assistance is limited to the period of receiving these services. The pilot program aims to provide child care services to qualified veterans receiving readjustment counseling and mental health services at Vet Centers. The program will be carried out in at least three selected Readjustment Counseling Service Regions for a duration of two years. The pilot program will provide child care assistance to qualified veterans receiving counseling and mental health services at Vet Centers in selected regions. Child care assistance may include stipends for licensed child care centers and payments to private child care providers. The pilot program provides child care assistance to qualified veterans at Vet Centers, including stipends for licensed child care centers and payments to private child care agencies. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress within 180 days after the program's completion. The report will contain findings, conclusions, and recommendations for the pilot program. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2014 and 2015. "Vet Center" is defined as a center for counseling and mental health services for veterans.
